subject: RE:  Re: A method for estimating number of junit test cases using Cyclomatic complexi
msgSnippet: Hi, The responses were invaluable. Thank you all. My manager hasn t shot me (yet). If I don t post again you can guess what would have happened to me. A few
messageBody:
Hi,
The responses were invaluable. Thank you all.
My manager hasn't shot me (yet). If I don't post again you can guess
what would have happened to me.

A few observations
2 hours is quite high.
I agree it looks quite high. Some initial experiments at actually
finding out how much time it takes to write a test method gave those
numbers. And, as mentioned by JBR, it is true that the existing code
will need to be refactored for meaningful junit tests. So 2 hours may be
the closer to actuals. One of the implicit ideas was to provide a
baseline model with 100% code coverage and reasonably accurate
complexity measures for classes, so that classes can be test infected
depending on the complexity and code coverage required.
As Bossicard pointed out, the final consensus in our team is to start
with Integration tests and write unit tests for those classes/packages
that throw up during integration testing. And, possibly use the
complexity measures to find which classes need to be tested and how much
they should be tested.
Dave is spot on. Dave, we are trying to do what you have said. [You need
to find places in the codebase that
would benefit the most from adding tests and go after those first.]

Best regards,
Selva.
"As small as possible. As soon as possible."
